sentence.idiomatic: I would rather you tell me the truth.
I would rather eat noodles than rice.
Don't tell me that you would rather to starve yourself?
I can handle it.
Can you deal with these troubles?
Do you have any problem handling him?
His performance hasn’t been very good recently.
I am satisfied with your performance.
Do you think the boss is satisfied with my performance?
Today you need to prepare a lot of information.
Are you prepared?
It took me three hours to prepare dinner.
Your answer is too vague.
It is an ambiguous theory.
Please don’t give me such an ambiguous answer.
Can you provide me with the resources I needed?
Shanghai City has a shortage of water resources.
Natural resources are becoming less and less.
Can I talk to you for a minute?
Of course.

word.literal: to be or not to be

sentence.idiomatic: Your performance hasn’t been very good recently. Are you having any trouble with work?
No, I can handle it.
You didn’t finish that report on time last week. This has happened several times in a row already. Is the workload too heavy?
It’s all right. Sir, I’m sorry. I’m not feeling very well these past few days. I will do my best.
Are you sure? We have a very important meeting next week. You need to prepare a lot of documents for it. Can you finish all of them by this Friday?
I shouldn’t have any problems.
I need a clear answer. Can you or can you not finish the work on time?
I will try my best. Don’t worry, sir.

word.literal: to be or not to be

sentence.idiomatic: I don’t want to hear ‘I’ll try my best.’ What I need is a clear answer from you on whether or not you will be able to finish the work on time. Are you having any difficulties? How can I help you get the job done?
Sir, actually there is one part I’m having trouble with. That’s why it dragged on for so long.

Next time something like this happens you need to tell me as soon as possible. I can get you the resources you needed. Even if you can’t do the work, I much prefer straightforward answers to ambiguous ones. From now on you must pay attention to that. Got it?
I get it. I’ll get it right.
Thank you.

word.literal: clearly demarcated between work and private affairs
